content:
Hmmmmm, kaj le vsi lezejo v Ljubljano ?

Zato je pa tako drago.

Na našem koncu za 70 jurjev solidna starejša hiška.

Za naveden denar, ki ga je plačala "Mojca" na podeželju sezidaš
luksuzno hiško.

Seveda ne na ključ ampak v lastni režiji, kot so to počeli že naši
starši.

No, mogoče pa bodo le ljudje kdaj skapirali.

author: MAN-1465775

ctx: Rastoče obrestne mere: zakaj bo Mojca za stanovanje v Šiški plačala sto tisoč evrov več kot lani
content:
kot zanimivost -

In Japan, houses are like cars.

As soon as you move in, your new home is worth less than what you
paid for it and after you've finished paying off your mortgage in
40 years, it is worth almost nothing.

It bewildered me when I first moved here as a correspondent for the
BBC - 10 years on, as I prepared to leave, it was still the
same.

Weirdly, this is presented as a chronic problem — something Japan
should have fixed long ago, but hasn’t. But in reality,
depreciating real estate is one of Japan’s biggest strengths.
Because Japanese people don’t use their houses as their nest eggs,
as they do in much of the West, there is not nearly as much
NIMBYism in Japan — people don’t fight tooth and nail to prevent
any local development that they worry might reduce their property
values, because their property values are going to zero
anyway.

As a result, Japanese cities like Tokyo have managed to build
enough housing to make housing costs fall, even as people continued
to stream from the countryside into the city.


noahpinion.substack....nged-a-lot
author: crt

ctx: Rastoče obrestne mere: zakaj bo Mojca za stanovanje v Šiški plačala sto tisoč evrov več kot lani
content:
Ta "Mojca" je imela ca 10 let časa, da stanovanje kupi ugodno - po
sprejemljivih cenah, s kreditom po zgodovinsko ugodni obrestni
meri. Tja, če je pa pričakovala, da bo pa vse samo še ceneje, se je
pač uštela v špekulativnih namenih...in sedaj je to to - vse
občutno dražje. Naj gre v najem in počaka na ugodnejši moment na
trgu. Ali pa špekulira kot že cel lajf do sedaj...in ne naredi nič.
author: MojemnenjeXXL

ctx: Rastoče obrestne mere: zakaj bo Mojca za stanovanje v Šiški plačala sto tisoč evrov več kot lani
content:
Mi res nismo zeleli prikazati, da je "Mojca" spekulant, al pa
trapasta, zeleli smo prikazati le, kako so spremenile razmere na
trgu posojil in pokazati, kaj pomeni cena stanovanja in cena na m2,
ce upostevamo stroske financiranja. sodb, ali je kdo kupil pametno
ali neumno, si res ne bi upal dajati - oz., med sklenjenimi posli
in vpisanimi hipotekami v zadnjem letu dni bi lahko nasli precej
takih, za katere bi lahko rekli, da so ravnali bolj noro/neumno
(recimo junija najeta posojila po 250k, pri cemer je nakup 80%
financiran s posojilom, OM pa vezana na 6m EURIBOR...). ampak spet
- ne poznamo njihovih osebnih okoliscin, prihodkov,...

content:

kot zanimivost -

In Japan, houses are like cars.

As soon as you move in, your new home is worth less than what you
paid for it and after you've finished paying off your mortgage in
40 years, it is worth almost nothing.

It bewildered me when I first moved here as a correspondent for the
BBC - 10 years on, as I prepared to leave, it was still the
same.

Weirdly, this is presented as a chronic problem — something Japan
should have fixed long ago, but hasn’t. But in reality,
depreciating real estate is one of Japan’s biggest strengths.
Because Japanese people don’t use their houses as their nest eggs,
as they do in much of the West, there is not nearly as much

noahpinion.substack....nged-a-lot

Če se svet japanizira, kake so možnosti, da se to zgodi
drugje.
Verjetno tudi japonci nimajo starih bajt vrednotenih skoraj nič že
od nekdaj.
Kot sem sam raziskoval k ceni starih hiš precej pripomore
spreminjanje zakonodaje glede gradnje, posledično ni zavarovanja in
posledično ni hipoteke.
So pa povprečne cene novih hiš nekje med 300 in 500k eur, vsaj ene
dve leti nazaj, če me spomin ne vara.
author: hostamox

ctx: Rastoče obrestne mere: zakaj bo Mojca za stanovanje v Šiški plačala sto tisoč evrov več kot lani
content:
[hostamox]> Če se svet
japanizira, kake so možnosti, da se to zgodi drugje.
japonci to dosegajo po mojem razumevanju na vec nacinov:

- s tem, da enostavno ni ljudi, ker je demografika v organu (kar se
slisi sicer logicno hehe), gastarbajterji pa so pripusceni bolj po
kapljicah in raje zacasno kot trajno, ceprav se kot receno v clanku
to zlagoma spreminja na bolj odprt pristop (vendar je prostora za
spremembo ogromnno)

- s tem, da jim kot receno v clanku ni noben problem graditi novih
kapacitet

- s tem, da imajo v velemmestih kakor razumem celo pristop, da se
po nekem casu stavbe tkoaltko rusijo in zgradijo nove
So pa povprečne cene novih hiš
nekje med 300 in 500k eur, vsaj ene dve leti nazaj, če me spomin ne
vara.
ne vem za hise, tukaj so stanovanja:

The average price of a second-hand apartment in central Tokyo is
nearing 100 million yen. The secret about Tokyo's high quality of
life and relative affordability for professionals is well and truly
out of the bag.

The phenomenon is partly due to the rise of the "power couple,"
dual-income professionals in which each partner earns >7 million
yen ($54,000). Tokyo is so affordable and money is so cheap that
it's enough to afford a downtown apartment, on a 0.4% 35-year
floating rate mortgage


twitter.com/GearoidR...SJtE6QTs_w

Zato, ker so se obrestne mere zvišale. Tako pač je zaradi okoliščin

Bolj smiselno bi bilo vprašanje, zakaj bo Mojca za stanovanje v

na to vprašanje je mnogo težji.
